sections.title: Keep Accounts Aligned With Your Estate Plan
sections.subtitle: Audit beneficiaries across accounts to avoid conflicts and delays

sections.title: What You'll Complete
items: Account inventory with primary and contingent beneficiaries
Naming conventions for minors, charities, and trusts
Trigger list of events requiring updates
Communication plan for heirs and fiduciaries

sections.title: Beneficiaries Override Wills
sections.content: Many assets—retirement accounts, life insurance, payable-on-death bank accounts—transfer based on beneficiary forms, not your will. Inconsistencies create disputes and unintended outcomes, so update designations whenever your estate plan changes.

points.title: Primary vs. Contingent
points.description: Name backups in case the primary beneficiary predeceases you or declines the inheritance.

points.title: Per Stirpes vs. Per Capita
points.description: Clarify how a beneficiary's share should pass to descendants if they are no longer living.

points.title: Trusts as Beneficiaries
points.description: Using a trust can add control for minor children or heirs who need structured distributions.

sections.title: Avoid Orphan Accounts
sections.content: Every account should list both primary and contingent beneficiaries. Missing designations force assets into probate.

sections.title: Beneficiary Audit Sprint
steps: List all accounts (401(k), IRA, brokerage, insurance, HSAs, bank) and note current designations.
Verify legal names, Social Security numbers, and percentages for each beneficiary.
Submit updated forms where needed—many providers offer electronic updates via secure portals.
Record confirmation emails or letters for your estate file.
Notify beneficiaries and fiduciaries about the updates, noting where documents are stored.

sections.title: Calendar Annual Reviews
sections.content: Set a recurring reminder every January to review designations alongside your insurance coverage and net worth statement.
